Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

description.narrative: Degree: bachelor's, master's and doctorate Non degree: Certificate and diploma

title.narrative: A.O.10. Diversity in management and teaching staff (i.e. balance in junior/senior staff, women/men, minorities)

description.narrative: please enclose stories of change or examples of best practices

actual.value: Only fact-finding, no changes made /activities performed in reporting period.

title.narrative: A.O.1. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the knowledge institution

description.narrative: please enclose stories of change or examples of best practices

actual.value: in 2019: only fact-finding, not changes made. In 2020: gender ratio fully balanced at UNAIR law faculty.

title.narrative: A.R.3. Number of relevant innovations
A.O.6. Number of facilities established/strengthened

comment.narrative: 28-01-2021: 2 PBL teaching rooms 1 Internship office 7 small moot courts rooms

title.narrative: A.S.2. Number of MoUs or other types of collaboration agreements signed (education, private, public, surrounding community)

comment.narrative: 28-01-2021: 6 MoUs between Indonesian Partners and UM 5 MoUs between UNAIR and Dissemination partners

title.narrative: A.O.9. Number of organisations with improved policies or procedures to encourage access to education of minorities

comment.narrative: 28-01-2021: Dissemination partners (5 universities in East Indonesia) are very active in our trainings and seminars; the educational content produced in the project benefits their students, who are (by location, plus often by ethnicity/religious affiliation) part of minority groups.

title.narrative: A.O.11. Number of organisations with policies and procedures to ensure an environment which is gender sensitive

comment.narrative: 28-01-2021: Gender-sensitivity is a topic and part of the content of both our trainings and the education material produced in the course. All participating institutions benefit from this.

title.narrative: A.E.6. Number of students enrolled in revised/newly developed study programmes

comment.narrative: 28-01-2021: Implementation of revised courses/curricula starting in fall 2020.

title.narrative: A.S.3. Number of students performing an internship or practical work

comment.narrative: 28-01-2021: Internship activities impeded by pandemic; numbers expected to increase in the future.

title.narrative: A.O.3. Number of organisations revised/developed institutional mechanism for quality assurance

comment.narrative: 28-01-2021: New quality assurance mechanisms are incorporated in new educational content, which ist first used in fall semester 2020.

title.narrative: A.R.2. Number of relevant publications (level, gender, inclusion)

comment.narrative: 28-01-2021: News bulletins, widely distributed and also submitted to NUFFIC

title.narrative: A.E.4. Number of graduates delivered

comment.narrative: 28-01-2021: Nu graduates as of yet, as implementation phase has only started. First graduates expected in 2021.

title.narrative: A.E.3. Number of staff that have gained qualitative and relevant knowledge and skills to develop and offer the revised/developed study programmes

comment.narrative: 28-01-2021: Opening seminar nov. 2019 in attendance of Dean FL UM: 90 participants. 22 UNAIR staff attended PBL training. Webinar legal ethics: 46 Webinar legal education in the digital age: 77

title.narrative: A.O.2. Number of organisations revised/developed and implemented a strategic plan

comment.narrative: 28-01-2021: Structures have been set up (internship office, PBL rooms, staff training). Strategic plan (at UNAIR and diss. partners) expected 2021.

title.narrative: A.O.12. Number of organisations with policies and procedures to ensure an environment which is conducive for minorities

comment.narrative: 28-01-2021: The position and rights of minorities are a topic and part of the content of both our trainings and the education material produced in the course. All participating institutions benefit from this.

title.narrative: A.E.1. Number of (knowledge) institutions supported directly

comment.narrative: 28-01-2021: UNAIR + 5 Dissemination Partners (as planned)

title.narrative: A.E.7. Student satisfaction

comment.narrative: 28-01-2021: Until the end of the reporting period, project activities focused entirely on teaching staff, no activity involving students. Hence nothing to report here.

comment.narrative: 28-01-2021: We do not understand the target value of 70% - what is this based on?

SROL.2 Rule of Law Strengthened: Citizens are better able to access their rights through fair, efficient, impartial, independent and accountable institutions
SROL.2.5. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) from marginalised groups who have improved access to their rights and judicial service facilities.

comment.narrative:
28-01-2021: Our project benefits the Rule of Law in the long term, but indirectly, through (a) contributing to educating better legal staff that will work in Indonesia's legal system, and (b) through creating awareness of the rule of law, citizens rights, and related issues. Both also benefits citizens from marginalized groups, in particular in the following ways: 1. collaboration with universities in marginalized regions ("dissemination partners") eases the education gap between these regions and Java; 2. Educational content developed in the project highlights the importance of the rights of ethnics and religious minorities, women, and disadvantaged groups.
No numerical value can be produced here.

SROL.3 Peace processes & political governance: States, regional and local authorities and societies at large are able to effectively prevent and resolve conflict in a non-violent and inclusive manner

comment.narrative: 28-01-2021: We have no way of measuring his, our projects supports the improvement of legal institutions in the long run and indirectly through educating better legal staff.

title.narrative: SROL.3.6. Number of national and/or local level conflict resolution and peacebuilding mechanisms supported
SROL.3.7. Number of beneficiaries with increased knowledge and skills to support policy influencing of incountry and regional conflict resolution and peacebuilding interventions

SROL.3.8. Number of beneficiaries with increased knowledge and skills to support interventions at national level to increase civil society engagement and at local level to increase community engagement in political decision-making
SROL.3.9. Number of beneficiaries with improved capacity for policy influencing on aspects of political governance and state building
SROL.3.3. Participation (and satisfaction) in governance processes (political decision-making, mediation and dialogue) by representation of various groups, with special reference to women and youth

actual.value: The rule of law, including state, regional and local authorities, their practices, and their accountability rules are still developing in Indonesia. Our project contributes to this development indirectly through education better qualified legal personnel.

title.narrative: SROL.3.4. Perception on accountability/transparency of governance structures

actual.value: The rule of law, including state, regional and local authorities, their practices, and their accountability rules are still developing in Indonesia. Our project contributes to this development indirectly through education better qualified legal personnel.
